discussion.content:
C is correct.

questions.question_text: What should the administrator do to monitor the size of the VM snapshot?

choices.A: Use native Guest OS monitoring tools.

questions.question_text:
An administrator is elevating the security posture of a vSphere environment after a recent data breach. All VMs will be encrypted as part of this plan.
Which additional component is required for the encryption?

discussion.content: Should be A the right answer, it’s talking about “an additional component” for the vsphere environment.

should be A
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-9035D542-B76B-4244-966D-2A8D92ABF54C.html

Should be A ! KMS is a requirement for VM Encryption, it's the server that stores the Encryption keys.
Plus, in the question they are asking for “an additional component” , Encrypted vMotion is a native feature not additional, and it would be used only in VM migration...

A is the correct answer.

A is Correct.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-9035D542-B76B-4244-966D-2A8D92ABF54C.html

vSphere Virtual Machine Encryption Components is an external KMS, the vCenter Server system, and your ESXi hosts are contributing to the vSphere Virtual Machine Encryption solution.

Need a KMS Server to enable Encryption
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5-1ejlPGEcU
The correct answer is A - KMS Server
The answer is A. Besides the reasons others have already posted here, Test4Sure also shows this Question's answer as the KSM server.
Correct answer A. Checked in exam.
I took the class a week ago, A is the correct answer. Encrypted vMotion is not necessary to encrypt a VM, but KMS is mandatory.
A. KMS is a must for VM encryption.

The answer is A. To use encripted vms you need to use an external third party component. The KMS! https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-9035D542-B76B-4244-966D-2A8D92ABF54C.html
Should be A

Same Correct answer is A i think.
We need a KMS Server to enable Encryption.

C makes no sense because VMotion is not even mentioned in the question. 
A is my preferred choice here.

D is Correct.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.avail.doc/GUID-2D395533-4C7C-45A6-9B5C-0A78C3E3A5C8.html
A vCenter HA cluster consists of three vCenter Server Appliance instances. The first instance, initially used as the Active node, is cloned twice to a Passive node and to a Witness node. Together, the three nodes provide an active-passive failover solution.
True, answer D

Answer D is correct
https://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/techpaper/vcha65-perf.pdf

questions.question_text: How is vCenter HA different from vSphere HA?

choices.D: vCenter HA requires an active, passive, and witness node.
choices.B: vCenter HA requires an external Platform Services Controller.
choices.A: vCenter HA requires only an active and passive node.

questions.question_text: Which file extension can export host customization for host profiles?

discussion.content:
If a host profile contains any customized attributes, you can export it to a .CSV file on your desktop.
For security, sensitive data such as passwords are not exported.

C is Correct.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.hostprofiles.doc/GUID-2E7398E2-1CF2-4448-96A3-1371B10936B1.html
correct link: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.hostprofiles.doc/GUID-2E7398E2-1CF2-4448-96A3-1371B10936B1.html

choices.C: Use vimtop to identify which processes are using high CPU.
choices.A: Verify if all hosts are in a connected state.
choices.B: Use esxtop to identify which process are using high CPU.
choices.E: Check if vCenter Server is swapping.

discussion.content:
C & E are correct.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.monitoring.doc/GUID-E5E062B2-4195-4DA5-A85D-6E47B6A53D14.html?hWord=N4IghgNiBcIGoEkCyAVA8gBRAXyA

To view the health of the swap in the vCenter Server Appliance, run the swap.health.get command.

comments.content: vimtop is for VCSA , esxtop is for esxi. you cant run esxtop on vcsa

discussion.content: Isn't vimtop and esxtop similar and both can monitor cpu usage?

questions.question_text:
A vSphere administrator notices performance issues with the vCenter Server Appliance. The CPU usage is over 70%.
Which two actions should the administrator take to investigate the performance issues? (Choose two.)
